key_points: A formal settlement was agreed upon for the Ever Given container ship that blocked the Suez Canal in March.
The Suez Canal Authority (SCA) has held the ship and its crew since it was dislodged on March 29.
The Ever Given was stuck in the canal for six days in March, disrupting global trade.
The settlement agreement will allow the Ever Given to sail on July 7.
Faz Peermohamed of Stann Marine, representing owner Shoei Kisen and its insurers, announced the settlement.
An event marking the agreement will be held at the SCA's headquarters in Ismailia.
The settlement includes the SCA receiving a tug boat with a pulling capacity of about 75 tonnes.
Osama Rabie, SCA chairman, emphasized the preservation of the authority's rights and international relations.
Despite the incident, the Suez Canal reported a revenue increase of 8.8% in the first half of 2021.
The SCA initially demanded $916 million in compensation, which was later publicly reduced to $550 million.
